title: Canberra couple celebrate 70th wedding anniversary
text:
Former champion show cook Pat Taylor, 87, has a simple recipe for a long and happy marriage. 
"I just think love one another," Mrs Taylor said. 
"And care for one another." 
Her husband Allen Taylor, 91, agreed this was the secret to their successful 70 years together. 
"It's the caring I'd say, more than anything," Mr Taylor said. 
The couple were still in their teens when they met in the New South Wales town of Hillston. 
It was 1943 and Mr Taylor, then 18, had been discharged from the Air Force to help his father on their farm. 
After a night at the movies with his mates, he spied his bride-to-be riding a pushbike under a streetlight. 
"And I said, 'who's that little sort over there?'" 
The following week Mr Taylor saw the girl again, this time walking with her friends. 
"She was on the outside, and I just touched her by the hand," he said. 
Mrs Taylor was four years younger and working at the local telephone exchange. 
They started going to dances and playing tennis together and gradually realised that they were meant for each another. Photo: Allen and Pat were married at the Church of England in Hillston on February 10, 1947. (Supplied: Taylor family) 
As Australia's population ages, the number of couples celebrating their platinum anniversary is set to rise. 
According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the number of people aged 85 and over increased by 141.2 per cent over the past two decades, compared with a total population growth of 32.4 per cent in the same period. 
But as there are also almost twice as many women as men in that age group, platinum anniversaries are still somewhat rare. Church wedding on a hot day in February 
The Taylors were married in the Church of England in Hillston on February 10, 1947 — a day they remember as "110 in the shade". 
The following morning, they caught the early train to Griffith where they dressed up again in their wedding clothes for a formal studio portrait. 
They spent their honeymoon in Sydney, spending one night at the People's Palace at Pitt Street and then three weeks at a Bondi boarding house run by two elderly women. 
"They were twins and they were funny as anything," Mrs Taylor said. 
They remember getting lost in the city and spending Friday nights at the Tivoli Theatre. 
Back home on the farm, the young couple began domestic life in a ramshackle old house. 
"It was built out of soft and hard timber, and white ants had eaten all the soft timber out, so it'd half collapsed," Mr Taylor said. 
"We spent nearly every night until 12 o'clock or more working on the house inside." 
They also built a huge workshop together; Mr Taylor was a talented bush mechanic, who in 1956 won the 6,500 miles (10,460 kilometres) Ampol Round Australia Trial with his mate Wilf Murrell. Tragedy brought couple closer together 
Mr and Mrs Taylor's first daughter Wendy was born the same year they married, followed by Susan, then Dennis. 
But in March 1952 tragedy struck when 15-month-old Susan accidentally ate ant poison. 
They rushed her to hospital, but after hours of trying to save her, she died. 
Mrs Taylor became ill from grief and took years to recover, including periods spent in mental health institutions. 
"I was [in a] very dark place for a long time," she said. 
But far from destroying their marriage, the terrible loss of their daughter brought the couple even closer together. 
Mr Taylor travelled with his wife to Sydney and Canberra seeking treatment for her depression. 
"I couldn't see her suffer," Mr Taylor said. 
"It was a terrible shock to both of us — I just happened to be, I suppose, a little bit stronger." A special, lasting bond 
In 1983, the Taylors sold their farm and retired to Canberra. 
They celebrated their 70th anniversary in January with a large family gathering but have planned a quiet day together on the actual date. Photo: The Taylors received messages from the Queen, Governor-General and Prime Minister. (ABC Radio Canberra: Louise Maher) 
Despite some arguments over the years — "I call him a silly old bugger ... quite a lot!" — Mrs Taylor said she relished the special bond she had with her husband. 
"He'll be going to say something to me and I'm thinking it and going to say it to him," she said. 
"Sometimes he says it first and sometimes I say it. 
"He's just a wonderful person — I love him to death." 
Mr Taylor said he had married "the most beautiful girl in Hillston". 
"We've always been there for one another right through our 70 years," he said. 
"We just got along well ... and hope to for a good while, until the day comes."
